rulings.text: A land that becomes a creature may be affected by “summoning sickness.” You can’t attack with it or use any of its {T} abilities (including its mana abilities) unless it began your most recent turn on the battlefield under your control. Note that summoning sickness cares about when that permanent came under your control, not when it became a creature.

When a land becomes a creature, that doesn’t count as having a creature enter the battlefield. The permanent was already on the battlefield; it only changed its types. Abilities that trigger whenever a creature enters the battlefield won’t trigger.

Any +1/+1 counters put on Raging Ravine remain on it even after it stops being a creature. They’ll have no effect until it becomes a creature again.

Thespian's Stage.name: Thespian's Stage
Thespian's Stage.text:
{T}: Add {C}.
{2}, {T}: Thespian's Stage becomes a copy of target land, except it has this ability.
Thespian's Stage.flavor: Amid rumors of war, the third act of *The Absolution of the Guildpact* was quickly rewritten as a tragedy.
Thespian's Stage.original_text:
{T}: Add {C}.
{2}, {T}: Thespian's Stage becomes a copy of target land, except it has this ability.

rulings.text: The copy effect created by the last activated ability doesn’t have a duration. It will last until Thespian’s Stage leaves the battlefield or another copy effect overwrites it. The permanent will no longer have the first ability of Thespian’s Stage.

A land’s copiable values are those printed on it, as modified by other copy effects. Counters and other effects aren’t copied. Notably, if you copy a land that is also a creature because of a temporary effect (such as Celestial Colonnade), Thespian’s Stage will become just the “unanimated” land.
Thespian’s Stage doesn’t become untapped when it becomes a copy, even if the target land is untapped.

No enters-the-battlefield abilities of the land Thespian’s Stage is copying will trigger. Thespian’s Stage was already on the battlefield. Similarly, no “as this land enters the battlefield” or “this land enters the battlefield with” effects, such as that of Dark Depths, will apply.

foreign_names.name: 演劇の舞台
foreign_names.text:
{T}：{C}を加える。

Urborg, Tomb of Yawgmoth.name: Urborg, Tomb of Yawgmoth
Urborg, Tomb of Yawgmoth.text: Each land is a Swamp in addition to its other land types.
Urborg, Tomb of Yawgmoth.flavor:
"Yawgmoth's corpse is a wound in the universe. His foul blood seeps out, infecting the land with his final curse."
—Lord Windgrace
Urborg, Tomb of Yawgmoth.original_text: Each land is a Swamp in addition to its other land types.

rulings.text: Urborg, Tomb of Yawgmoth isn’t a Swamp while it’s not on the battlefield.
Land cards not on the battlefield aren’t Swamps while Urborg is on the battlefield.

Urborg’s ability causes each land on the battlefield to have the land type Swamp. Any land that’s a Swamp has the ability “{T}: Add {B}.” Nothing else changes about those lands, including their names, other subtypes, other abilities, and whether they’re legendary, basic, or snow.

If an effect such as that of Magus of the Moon causes Urborg to lose its abilities by setting it to a basic land type not in addition to its other types, it won’t turn lands into Swamps, no matter in what order those effects started to apply.

Whenever an opponent says the chosen word, Keeper of the Sacred Word gets +3/+3 until end of turn.

Laughing Hyena.name: Laughing Hyena
Laughing Hyena.text: Gotcha — If an opponent laughs, you may say "Gotcha!" When you do, return Laughing Hyena from your graveyard to your hand.
Laughing Hyena.flavor: "Two muffins are baking in an oven. One muffin says to the other muffin, 'It's getting hot in here, huh?' The other muffin says, 'Aagh! A talking muffin!'"
Laughing Hyena.original_text: Gotcha Whenever an opponent laughs, you may say "Gotcha" If you do, return Laughing Hyena from your graveyard to your hand.

Time Machine.original_text: {T}: Remove Time Machine and target nontoken creature you own from the game. Return both cards to play at the beginning of your upkeep on your turn X of the next game you play with the same opponent, where X is the removed creature's converted mana cost.

AWOL.name: AWOL
AWOL.text: Exile target attacking creature. Then remove it from the game. Then put it into the absolutely-removed-from-the-freaking-game-forever zone.

Bosom Buddy.original_text: Whenever you play a spell, you may gain ½ life for each word in that spell's name.

Cardpecker.name: Cardpecker
Cardpecker.text:
Flying
Gotcha — If an opponent touches the table with their hand, you may say "Gotcha!" When you do, return Cardpecker from your graveyard to your hand.

Emcee.name: Emcee
Emcee.text: Whenever another creature enters the battlefield, you may stand up and say in a deep, booming voice, "Presenting . . . " and that creature's name. If you do, put a +1/+1 counter on that creature.
Emcee.flavor: The ogre appealed the match loss and got it downgraded to a warning.

rulings.text: If you control more than one Emcee, each ability triggers separately. You have to announce the creature’s entrance each time. Okay, you can just stay standing if you want.
Emcee’s ability will trigger whenever a creature enters the battlefield under an opponent’s control. You choose whether you announce its arrival or not.

You may add in nicknames for the creatures you announce, but you must also get the creature’s actual name in there to count. For example, “Gary, the Gray Merchant of Asphodel” is fine, but simply “Gary” wouldn’t work.
If you are unable (not just unwilling) to use a deep, booming voice, you are free to make accommodations in the spirit of Emcee. Sign overly dramatically, for example.

Erase (Not the Urza's Legacy One).name: Erase (Not the Urza's Legacy One)

Erase (Not the Urza's Legacy One).artist: Pete “Yes the Urza's Legacy One” Venters
Erase (Not the Urza's Legacy One).original_text:
If you control two or more white permanents that share an artist, you may play Erase (Not the Urza's Legacy One) without paying its mana cost.
Remove target enchantment from the game.

Fascist Art Director.original_text: {W}{W}: Fascist Art Director gains protection from the artist of your choice until end of turn..

First Come, First Served.name: First Come, First Served
First Come, First Served.text: Each attacking or blocking creature with the lowest collector number among attacking or blocking creatures has first strike.
First Come, First Served.flavor: Yotian soldiers hoped that one day R&D would make an artifact creature whose name starts with Z. And in their dreams, it's a 4/1.
First Come, First Served.original_text: The attacking or blocking creature with the lowest collector number has first strike. If two or more creatures are tied, they all have first strike.

Gleemax.name: Gleemax
Gleemax.text: You choose all targets for all spells and abilities.
Gleemax.flavor: Help us . . . R&D under mental domination of alien brain in jar . . . only chance . . . Gleemax's blatant disregard for flavor text . . . send help!
Gleemax.original_text: You choose all targets for all spells and abilities.

Letter Bomb.name: Letter Bomb
Letter Bomb.text: When Letter Bomb enters the battlefield, sign it and shuffle it into target player's library. That player reveals each card they draw until they draw Letter Bomb. When that player draws Letter Bomb, it deals 19½ damage to them.
Letter Bomb.original_text: When Letter Bomb comes into play, sign it and shuffle it into target player's library. That player reveals each card he or she draws until Letter Bomb is drawn. When that player draws Letter Bomb, it deals 19½ damage to him or her.

Frankie Peanuts.name: Frankie Peanuts
Frankie Peanuts.text: At the beginning of your upkeep, you may ask target player a yes-or-no question. If you do, that player answers the question truthfully and abides by that answer if able until end of turn.
Frankie Peanuts.flavor: Don't cross him or you'll end up sleeping with the merfolk.
Frankie Peanuts.original_text: At the beginning of your upkeep, you may ask target player a yes-or-no question. If you do, that player answers the question truthfully and abides by that answer if able until end of turn.

rulings.text: If you’re the player answering the yes-or-no question, you must abide by your answer if able. For example, if you are asked “Is the Slaying Mantis you control going to attack on your next turn?” and you say yes, then it must attack if able. However, if it’s tapped as you declare attackers that turn, then you aren’t able to attack with it, and you don’t have to abide by your answer.
Frankie Peanuts hates snitches, but he detests unsporting conduct. Keep your questions appropriate for your game and its surroundings.

Head to Head.name: Head to Head
Head to Head.text: You and target opponent play Seven Questions with the top card of that player's library. If you win, prevent all damage that would be dealt this turn by a source of your choice. (To play Seven Questions, that player looks at the card, then you ask up to six yes-or-no questions about the card that they answer truthfully. You guess the card's name—that's question seven—then the player reveals the card.)
Head to Head.original_text: You and target opponent play Seven Questions about the top card of that player's library. (That player looks at the card, then you ask up to six yes-or-no questions about the card that he or she answers truthfully. You guess the card's name—that's question seven—and the player reveals the card.) If you win, prevent all damage that would be dealt this turn by a source of your choice.

Ladies' Knight.name: Ladies' Knight

Flying

Ladies' Knight.original_text:
Flying
Spells that players wearing at least one item of women's clothing play cost {1} less to play. (Women's clothing is designed to be worn exclusively by women.)

Look at Me, I'm R&D.name: Look at Me, I'm R&D
Look at Me, I'm R&D.text:

All instances of the first chosen number on permanents, spells, and cards in any zone are the second chosen number.
Look at Me, I'm R&D.original_text:
As Look at Me, I'm R&D comes into play, choose a number and a second number one higher or one lower than that number.
All instances of the first chosen number on permanents, spells, and cards in any zone are the second chosen number.

rulings.text: Look at Me, I’m R&D applies to all numbers that appear on the card, including numbers in mana symbols, rules text, power, toughness, collector number, and art.
You can choose a number with a fraction.
Note that you are changing numbers, not numerals within a number. Choosing 2 and 3 won’t change 20 to 30 or ½ to ⅓.
If you choose 0 for the first number, you are allowed to choose -1 for the second. The same is true for ½ and -½.

Man of Measure.original_text:

Ambiguity.original_text: Whenever a player plays a spell that counters a spell that has been played or a player plays a spell that comes into play with counters, that player may counter the next spell played or put an additional counter on a permanent that has already been played, but not countered.

Avatar of Me.name: Avatar of Me
Avatar of Me.text:
This spell costs {1} more to cast for each ten years you've been alive.
Avatar of Me's power is equal to your height in feet and its toughness is equal to your American shoe size. Round to the nearest ½.
Avatar of Me is the color of your eyes.
Avatar of Me.original_text:
Avatar of Me costs {1} more to play for each ten years you've been alive.
Avatar of Me's power is equal to your height in feet and its toughness is equal to your American shoe size. Round to the nearest ½.
Avatar of Me's color is the color of your eyes.

rulings.text: Avatar of Me is only the color of your eyes, not the color of your eyes and blue. That is, the color it gets from its last ability overrides the blue it gets from its mana cost.
Silver-bordered rules include any conceivable eye color, not just the five traditional Magic colors. If your eye are hazel, Avatar of Me is hazel.

Thanks to Avatar of Me, if you’re asked to choose a color in a silver-bordered game, you can name any color. “That dreamy shade of blue found only in the sky on a perfect afternoon… and in your eyes” is acceptable, but a little weird.
If you’re wearing colored contact lenses, Avatar of Me is whatever color your eyes appear to be. You can add or remove contact lenses to change your eye color in response to spells and abilities.
If each of your eyes is a different color (naturally or via a single contact lens), Avatar of Me is both colors.

rulings.text: You must say the flavor text out loud or use a comparable method of communicating. For example, sign language is allowed, but if you sign the flavor text, you are considered to have spoken. Goblin Mime will notice.

Mouth to Mouth.original_text: You and target opponent have a breath-holding contest. If you win, you gain control of target creature that player controls.

Richard Garfield, Ph.D..name: Richard Garfield, Ph.D.
Richard Garfield, Ph.D..text: You may play cards as though they were other cards of your choice with the same mana cost. You can't choose the same card twice. (Mana cost includes color.)
Richard Garfield, Ph.D..flavor: And yea he doth spake: "Let there be Magic."

rulings.text: Richard Garfield, Ph.D. essentially makes you play a variant of the Magic game called “Mental Magic.” Here’s how the game works. Whenever you cast a spell, you reveal the card to all players and choose any other card (see below for the cards that you can use) that has that card’s mana cost. (Note that color very much does matter.) That spell can then be cast as though it was the chosen card. You aren’t allowed to choose the same card twice.

By default, you are limited to cards legal in the format you’re playing. If you’re playing Draft or Sealed Deck, you can name any card available in the format you’re playing. If you’re playing with Unsanctioned decks, anything goes. Discuss with your playgroup if you’d prefer to modify or eliminate these limitations.
Playing cards as though they were other cards is optional.
Each Richard tracks its own list of played cards. If one leaves the battlefield and another enters, cards previously played under the first Richard are available once again.

If more than one player controls a Richard Garfield, Ph.D., the cards one player plays has no effect on the other players. For example, each player could play Savannah Lions as a Swords to Plowshares this way.

The same is true if Richard Garfield, Ph.D. changes controllers. If you play a Savannah Lions as Swords to Plowshares, then an opponent gains control of Richard Garfield, Ph.D., that player can then do the same.

Aesthetic Consultation.name: Aesthetic Consultation
Aesthetic Consultation.text: Choose an artist. Exile the top six cards of your library, then reveal cards from the top of your library until you reveal a card with art by the chosen artist. Put that card in your hand and exile all other cards revealed this way.

Bad Ass.name: Bad Ass
Bad Ass.flavor: He wanders the land in search of Good Ass.

Farewell to Arms.name: Farewell to Arms
Farewell to Arms.text:
As Farewell to Arms enters the battlefield, choose a hand attached to an opponent's arm.
When the chosen hand isn't behind its owner's back, sacrifice Farewell to Arms. If you do, that player discards their hand . . . of cards. (The lawyers wouldn't let us do it the other way.)

Infernal Spawn of Infernal Spawn of Evil.name: Infernal Spawn of Infernal Spawn of Evil
Infernal Spawn of Infernal Spawn of Evil.text:
Flying, first strike, trample
Once each turn, while you're searching your library, you may pay {1}{B}, reveal Infernal Spawn of Infernal Spawn of Evil from your library and say "I'm coming, too!" If you do, Infernal Spawn of Infernal Spawn of Evil deals 2 damage to a player of your choice.
Infernal Spawn of Infernal Spawn of Evil.original_text:
Flying, first strike, trample
If you say "I'm coming, too" as you search your library, you may pay {1}{B} and reveal Infernal Spawn of Infernal Spawn of Evil from your library to have it deal 2 damage to a player of your choice. Do this no more than once each turn.

rulings.text: Infernal Spawn of Infernal Spawn of Evil doesn’t itself allow you to search your library. You must have another spell or ability that instructs you to search it.
You can reveal Infernal Spawn of Infernal Spawn of Evil any time while searching your library before you shuffle it.
If you have multiple copies in your library while searching it, you may reveal all of them, provided you can pay the {1}{B} for each of them.

If you search your library multiple times in the same turn, each Infernal Spawn of Infernal Spawn of Evil in that library can be revealed once that turn. You may reveal multiples to prove you have multiples.

Kill! Destroy!.original_text:
Destroy target nonblack creature.
Gotcha Whenever an opponent says "Kill" or "Destroy," you may say "Gotcha" If you do, return Kill Destroy from your graveyard to your hand.

Booster Tutor.name: Booster Tutor
Booster Tutor.text: Open a sealed Magic booster pack, reveal the cards, and put one of them into your hand. (Remove that card from your deck before beginning a new game.)
Booster Tutor.original_text: Open a sealed Magic booster pack, reveal the cards, and put one of those cards into your hand. (Remove that card from your deck before beginning a new game.)

rulings.text: You can use any sealed Magic booster pack, including promo packs. As long as it hasn’t previously been opened and you don’t know the contents beforehand, you’re good.
You can open booster packs that contain cards not legal in the format you’re playing.

Duh.name: Duh
Duh.text: Destroy target creature with reminder text. (Reminder text is any italicized text in parentheses that explains rules you already know.)
Duh.flavor: Will players understand that the creature is being crushed by two parentheses? Not a chance.
Duh.original_text: Destroy target creature with reminder text. (Reminder text is any italicized text in parentheses that explains rules you already know.)

rulings.text: Look at the actual creature you’re hoping to destroy to see if it has reminder text. Its Oracle text doesn’t matter for this purpose. It also doesn’t matter if another printing of the creature has (or doesn’t have) reminder text.
Duh can target a creature token only if the object you’re using to represent the token has reminder text, even if it’s a copy of a creature with reminder text.

Enter the Dungeon.name: Enter the Dungeon
Enter the Dungeon.text: Players play a Magic subgame under the table, starting at 5 life and using their libraries as their decks. The winner searches their library for two cards, puts those cards into their hand, then shuffles.
Enter the Dungeon.original_text: Players play a Magic subgame under the table starting at 5 life, using their libraries as their decks. After the subgame ends, the winner searches his or her library for two cards, puts those cards into his or her hand, then shuffles his or her library.

rulings.text: If Enter the Dungeon is cast during a subgame, a sub-subgame begins, preferably under a new, smaller table, but do what you can. The winner of the sub-sub game would search their subgame library for two cards.

Eye to Eye.name: Eye to Eye
Eye to Eye.text: You and target creature's controller have a staring contest. If you win, destroy that creature.
Eye to Eye.flavor: True, Gargox had blinded himself for life, but the glass eyes never lost.
Eye to Eye.original_text: You and target creature's controller have a staring contest. If you win, destroy that creature.

Mother of Goons.name: Mother of Goons
Mother of Goons.text: Whenever a creature an opponent controls dies, sacrifice Mother of Goons unless you insult that creature.
Mother of Goons.original_text: Whenever a creature an opponent controls is put into a graveyard from play, sacrifice Mother of Goons unless you insult that creature.

Assquatch.name: Assquatch

Whenever another Donkey enters the battlefield, untap target creature and gain control of it until end of turn. That creature gains haste until end of turn.

Assquatch.original_text:
Each other Donkey gets +1½/+1½.
Whenever another Donkey comes into play, untap target creature and gain control of it until end of turn. That creature gains haste until end of turn.

B-I-N-G-O.name: B-I-N-G-O
B-I-N-G-O.text:
Trample
Whenever a player casts a spell, put a chip counter on its mana value.
B-I-N-G-O gets +9/+9 for each set of three numbers in a row with chip counters on them.
B-I-N-G-O.flavor: There was a farmer, had a hound . . .
B-I-N-G-O.original_text:
Trample
Whenever a player plays a spell, put a chip counter on its converted mana cost.
B-I-N-G-O gets +9/+9 for each set of three numbers in a row with chip counters on them.

rulings.text: All nine rows count. You can fill rows horizontally, vertically, and diagonally. A full card with give B-I-N-G-O +72/+72.
Casting multiple spells with the same mana value has no additional benefit. Once a spot has a chip counter, it’s marked, and additional chip counters won’t do anything.

The counters are considered to be on the inherent tracker in B-I-N-G-O’s art, not on the creature itself. Those counters can’t be removed or moved to another permanent. Similarly, if you proliferate, you can’t add more chip counters to B-I-N-G-O.

Creature Guy.name: Creature Guy
Creature Guy.text: Gotcha — If an opponent says "creature" or "guy," you may say "Gotcha!" When you do, return Creature Guy from your graveyard to your hand.
Creature Guy.flavor: There once was a player named Quinn, . . .
Creature Guy.original_text: Gotcha Whenever an opponent says "Creature" or "Guy," you may say "Gotcha" If you do, return Creature Guy from your graveyard to your hand.

\"Ach! Hans, Run!\".name: "Ach! Hans, Run!"
\"Ach! Hans, Run!\".text: At the beginning of your upkeep, you may say "Ach! Hans, run! It's the . . ." and the name of a creature card. If you do, search your library for a card with that name, put it onto the battlefield, then shuffle. That creature gains haste. Exile it at the beginning of the next end step.
\"Ach! Hans, Run!\".original_text: At the beginning of your upkeep, you may say "Ach Hans, run It's the . . ." and name a creature card. If you do, search your library for the named card, put it into play, then shuffle your library. That creature has haste. Remove it from the game at end of turn.

Ass Whuppin'.name: Ass Whuppin'

Ass Whuppin'.original_text: Destroy target silver-bordered permanent in any game you can see from your seat.

Mana Screw.name: Mana Screw
Mana Screw.text: {1}: Flip a coin. If you win the flip, add {C}{C}. Activate only as an instant.
Mana Screw.flavor: There was no darker or more evil creation in all the multiverse than that of the mana screw.

Blast from the Past.name: Blast from the Past
Blast from the Past.text:
Madness {R}, cycling {1}{R}, kicker {2}{R}, flashback {3}{R}, buyback {4}{R}
Blast from the Past deals 2 damage to any target. If this spell was kicked, create a 1/1 red Goblin creature token.

rulings.text: If you cycle Blast from the Past, you can then use madness to cast it. If you cast Blast from the Past using madness, you may also pay for kicker or buyback.
Flashback and buyback don’t mix. If you cast Blast from the Past using flashback, it will be exiled rather than go back to your hand.
Flashback and kicker do mix. You can pay the kicker cost in addition to the flashback cost to get the extra Goblin token.

Frazzled Editor.name: Frazzled Editor
Frazzled Editor.text: Protection from wordy (Something is wordy if it has four or more lines of rules text.)
Frazzled Editor.flavor: The pen is mightier than the sword.

Saut\u00e9.name: Sauté
Saut\u00e9.text: Sauté deals 3½ damage to any target.
Saut\u00e9.flavor:
"Selecting the proper beeble is the key to a good sauté. The pinker the fur and the heartier the yelp, the more succulent the beeble will be when you pop it in your mouth."
—Asmoranomardicadaistinaculdacar, *The Underworld Cookbook*
Saut\u00e9.original_text: Sauté deals 3½ damage to target creature or player.

Elvish House Party.name: Elvish House Party

Elvish House Party.flavor: The party was going strong for nearly an hour past midnight—then all of a sudden it just petered out.
Elvish House Party.original_text: Elvish House Party's power and toughness are each equal to the current hour, using the twelve-hour system.

Fat Ass.name: Fat Ass
Fat Ass.text: Fat Ass gets +2/+2 and has trample as long as you're eating. (Gum isn't food. We checked.)
Fat Ass.flavor: Our lawyers say no matter how funny it would be, we can't encourage players to eat the cards. Hear that? Whatever you do, *don't* eat the delicious cards.
Fat Ass.original_text: Fat Ass gets +2/+2 and has trample as long as you're eating. (Food is in your mouth and you're chewing, licking, sucking, or swallowing it.)

Form of the Squirrel.name: Form of the Squirrel

You have shroud.
You can't cast spells.
Form of the Squirrel.original_text:
As Form of the Squirrel comes into play, put a 1/1 green Squirrel creature token into play. You lose the game when it leaves play.
Creatures can't attack you.
You can't be the target of spells or abilities.
You can't play spells.

Fraction Jackson.original_text: {G}, {T}: Return target card with a ½ on it from your graveyard to your hand.

Rocket-Powered Turbo Slug.text: Super haste (This may attack the turn before you cast it. Name Dropping.name: Name Dropping
Name Dropping.text: Gotcha — If an opponent says a word that's in the name of a card in your graveyard, you may say "Gotcha!" When you do, return that card to your hand.
Name Dropping.flavor: Gemini (May 21—June 21) This week is a good time to branch out and meet others. But don't forget your roots. Avoid commitments and open flames.
Name Dropping.original_text: Gotcha Whenever an opponent says a word that's in the name of a card in your graveyard, you may say "Gotcha" If you do, return that card to your hand.

Old Fogey.name: Old Fogey
Old Fogey.text: Phasing, cumulative upkeep {1}, echo {G}{G}, fading 3, bands with other Dinosaurs, protection from Homarids, snow-covered plainswalk, flanking, rampage 2
Old Fogey.flavor: "These kids today with their collector numbers and their newfangled tap symbol. Twenty Black Lotuses and twenty Plague Rats. Now that's *real* Magic."
Old Fogey.original_text: Phasing, cumulative upkeep {1}, echo, fading 3, bands with other Dinosaurs, protection from Homarids, snow-covered plainswalk, flanking, rampage 2

rulings.text: Due to changes in how echo and phasing work since Old Fogey was originally printed, echo mostly does nothing in this case. This is, as they say, a bit weird. Old Fogey is phased out when its echo ability would trigger, so that ability doesn’t trigger at the beginning of the upkeep after Old Fogey enters the battlefield. Phasing in doesn’t cause Old Fogey to enter the battlefield, so echo ends up not really doing much at all.

Nonland cards with the chosen word in their text box can't be played.

Smart Ass.name: Smart Ass
Smart Ass.text: Whenever Smart Ass attacks, choose a card name. If defending player has no cards with the chosen name in their hand, they may reveal their hand. If they don't reveal their hand, Smart Ass can't be blocked this turn.

Spell Counter.original_text:

Topsy Turvy.name: Topsy Turvy
Topsy Turvy.text:
The phases of each player's turn are reversed. (The phases are, in reverse order, ending, postcombat main, combat, precombat main, and beginning.)
As long as there are more than two players in the game, the turn order is reversed.
Topsy Turvy.flavor: "Here on going is heck the what?"
Topsy Turvy.original_text:
The phases of each player's turn are reversed. (The phases are, in reverse order, end, postcombat main, combat, precombat main, and beginning.)
If there are more than two players in the game, the turn order is reversed.

rulings.text: Steps within each phase play out as normal. For example, although the beginning phase happens last in a turn, the untap, upkeep, and draw steps happen in their traditional order. (If it were the other way, combat would require psychics to get through.)
Any even number of Topsy Turvys (Turvies?) will essentially cancel each other out and return the order of phases to their normal order.

Whenever damage is dealt to The Fallen Apart, remove an arm or a leg from it.
The Fallen Apart can't attack if it has no legs and can't block if it has no arms.
The Fallen Apart.original_text:
The Fallen Apart comes into play with two arms and two legs.
Whenever damage is dealt to The Fallen Apart, remove an arm or a leg from it.
The Fallen Apart can't attack if it has no legs and can't block if it has no arms.

Persecute Artist.original_text: Choose an artist other than Rebecca Guay. Target player reveals his or her hand and discards all nonland cards by the chosen artist.

Red-Hot Hottie.name: Red-Hot Hottie
Red-Hot Hottie.text: Whenever Red-Hot Hottie deals damage to a creature, put a third-degree-burn counter on that creature. It gains "At the beginning of each end step, sacrifice this creature unless you scream 'Aaah!' at the top of your lungs."
Red-Hot Hottie.flavor: She was winning the Dominarian "Are You Hot?" competition until disaster struck during the wet T-shirt round.

Whenever Red-Hot Hottie deals damage to a creature, put a third-degree-burn counter on that creature. It has "At the end of each turn, sacrifice this creature unless you scream ‘

Six-y Beast.name: Six-y Beast
Six-y Beast.text: As Six-y Beast enters the battlefield, you secretly put six or fewer +1/+1 counters on it, then an opponent guesses the number of counters. If that player guesses right, sacrifice Six-y Beast after it enters the battlefield.
Six-y Beast.original_text: As Six-y Beast comes into play, you secretly put six or fewer +1/+1 counters on it, then an opponent guesses the number of counters. If that player guesses right, sacrifice Six-y Beast.

Touch and Go.name: Touch and Go
Touch and Go.text:
Destroy target land.
Gotcha — If an opponent touches their face, you may say "Gotcha!" When you do, return Touch and Go from your graveyard to your hand.
Touch and Go.flavor: Judge's ruling: The interior of the face still counts as the face, so a nose-pick is legitimate grounds for saying "Gotcha"

Yet Another Aether Vortex.name: Yet Another Aether Vortex
Yet Another Aether Vortex.text:
All creatures have haste.
Players play with the top card of their libraries revealed.
Noninstant, nonsorcery cards on top of a library are on the battlefield under their owner's control in addition to being in that library.
Yet Another Aether Vortex.original_text:
All creatures have haste.
Players play with the top card of their libraries revealed.
Noninstant, nonsorcery cards on top of a library are in play under their owner's control in addition to being in that library.

rulings.text: If the top card of your library is a creature, planeswalker, land, enchantment, or artifact card, it’s also on the battlefield. Ta-da! This is, as they say, very weird.
If the top card of your library is a creature card, it can attack. It does have haste, after all. It can also block.

If the top card of your library is a permanent card with an activated ability that requires it to be tapped, that ability can be activated. Land cards on top of your library can be tapped for mana, and so on.

A permanent card that becomes the top card of your library enters the battlefield (unless it went from the battlefield to the top of your library), so any enters-the-battlefield abilities will trigger and “as [this creature] enters the battlefield” abilities will apply. Similarly, a permanent card that stops being the top card of your library leaves the battlefield (unless it went from the top of your library to the battlefield directly).
If the top card of your library is a creature card and it’s put into your graveyard, the creature did die. Note that it wasn’t destroyed or sacrificed or anything. It just died. <sad trombone noises>

If a creature you control that isn’t part of your library is put on top of your library, surprisingly little happens, at least at first. That creature doesn’t leave or enter the battlefield. It just stays on the battlefield. Of course, now that it’s also the top card of your library, you’ll probably draw it soon. This is also true if something puts the top card of your library directly onto the battlefield, without you having to play it.
If the top card is your library is an Aura card, that Aura is on the battlefield not attached to anything. As such, it’s put into your graveyard. The new top card of your library is then revealed.

If you are instructed to draw multiple cards, you draw them one at a time. Each card you draw after the first becomes the top card of your library briefly and is revealed. Each permanent card revealed this way enters and then leaves the battlefield, for any abilities that care about that.

Remodel.name: Remodel
Remodel.text:
If you control two or more green permanents that share an artist, you may cast this spell without paying its mana cost.
Exile target artifact.
Remodel.flavor: 6 PM (23) This Old Grove 98055 A rusted masticore makes a beautiful addition to any garden.
Remodel.original_text:
If you control two or more green permanents that share an artist, you may play Remodel without paying its mana cost.
Remove target artifact from the game.

Side to Side.name: Side to Side
Side to Side.text: You and target opponent arm-wrestle. If you win, create a 3/3 green Ape creature token.
Side to Side.flavor: His friends at the gym never knew Garanth's secret shame. For years he had tried to walk away from professional arm wrestling, but hey—free monkeys.
Side to Side.original_text: You and target opponent arm-wrestle. If you win, put a 3/3 green Ape creature token into play.

S.N.O.T..name: S.N.O.T.
S.N.O.T..text:
You may have S.N.O.T. enter the battlefield stuck to another creature named S.N.O.T. If you do, all those creatures form a single creature.
S.N.O.T.'s power and toughness are each equal to the square of the number of cards named S.N.O.T. stuck together to form it. (One is a 1/1, two are a 4/4, three are a 9/9, and four are a 16/16. If you manage to get -1 S.N.O.T.s stuck together, it's a 1/1.)
S.N.O.T..original_text:
As S.N.O.T. comes into play, you may stick it onto another creature named S.N.O.T. in play. If you do, all those creatures form a single creature.
S.N.O.T.'s power and toughness are equal to the square of the number of S.N.O.T.s stuck together. (One is a 1/1, two are a 4/4, three are a 9/9, and four are a 16/16.)

Stone-Cold Basilisk.name: Stone-Cold Basilisk
Stone-Cold Basilisk.text:
Whenever Stone-Cold Basilisk blocks or becomes blocked by a creature with fewer letters in its name, destroy that creature at end of combat. (Punctuation and spaces aren't letters.)
Whenever an opponent reads Stone-Cold Basilisk, that player is turned to stone until end of turn. Stoned players can't attack, block, cast spells, or activate abilities.
Stone-Cold Basilisk.original_text:
Whenever Stone-Cold Basilisk blocks or becomes blocked by a creature with fewer letters in its name, destroy that creature at end of combat. (Punctuation and spaces aren't letters.)
Whenever an opponent reads Stone-Cold Basilisk, that player is turned to stone until end of turn. Stoned players can't attack, block, or play spells or abilities.

Supersize.name: Supersize
Supersize.text: Target creature gets +3½/+3½ until end of turn.
Supersize.original_text: Target creature gets +3½/+3½ until end of turn.

Symbol Status.original_text: Put a 1/1 colorless Expansion-Symbol creature token into play for each different expansion symbol among permanents you control.

Rare-B-Gone.name: Rare-B-Gone
Rare-B-Gone.text: Each player sacrifices all permanents that are rare or mythic rare, then each player reveals their hand and discards all cards that are rare or mythic rare.
Rare-B-Gone.flavor: The only rare you'll ever need. Okay, not really.
Rare-B-Gone.original_text: Each player sacrifices all rare permanents, then reveals his or her hand and discards all rare cards.

Pointy Finger of Doom.name: Pointy Finger of Doom
Pointy Finger of Doom.text: {3}, {T}: Spin Pointy Finger of Doom in the middle of the table so that it rotates completely at least once, then destroy the closest permanent the finger points to.
Pointy Finger of Doom.flavor:
"I would have made a 'Spin-The-Bottle' joke if I thought anyone reading this had ever played the game."
—Bucky, flavor text writer
Pointy Finger of Doom.original_text: {3}, {T}: Spin Pointy Finger of Doom in the middle of the table so that it rotates completely at least once, then destroy the closest permanent the finger points to.

rulings.text: Pointy Finger of Doom must rotate at least 360 degrees to count. There is no penalty for failing to spin it properly other than you must try again.
Pointy Finger of Doom won’t destroy itself, even though it is very close to itself.
Once the Finger starts spinning, no permanents can be moved until after the ability completely resolves.
If you create a token that’s a copy of Pointy Finger of Doom, spin whatever object you’re using to represent the token. Do not use living beings to represent the token.

Rod of Spanking.text: {2}, {T}: Rod of Spanking deals 1 damage to target player. Then untap Rod of Spanking unless that player says "Thank you, sir. May I have another?"
Rod of Spanking.flavor: Minutes before the campus watch busted pledge week at the Alpha Beta Unlimited house . . .
Rod of Spanking.original_text: {2}, {T}: Rod of Spanking deals 1 damage to target player. Then untap Rod of Spanking unless that player says "Thank you, sir. May I have another?"

Togglodyte.name: Togglodyte
Togglodyte.text:
Togglodyte enters the battlefield turned on.
Whenever a player casts a spell, toggle Togglodyte's ON/OFF switch.
As long as Togglodyte is turned off, it can't attack or block, and prevent all damage it would deal.
Togglodyte.original_text:
Togglodyte comes into play turned on.
Whenever a player plays a spell, toggle Togglodyte's ON/OFF switch.
As long as Togglodyte is turned off, it can't attack or block, and all damage it would deal is prevented.

Toy Boat.name: Toy Boat
Toy Boat.text: Cumulative upkeep—Say "Toy Boat" quickly. (At the beginning of your upkeep, put an age counter on Toy Boat, then sacrifice it unless you say "Toy Boat" once for each age counter on it—without pausing between or fumbling it.)
Toy Boat.original_text:
Cumulative upkeep—
Say "Toy Boat" quickly. (At the beginning of your upkeep, put an age counter on Toy Boat, then sacrifice it unless you say "Toy Boat" once for each age counter on it—without pausing between or fumbling it.)

Urza's Hot Tub.name: Urza's Hot Tub
Urza's Hot Tub.text: {2}, Discard a card: Search your library for a card that shares a complete word in its name with the discarded card, reveal it, put it into your hand, then shuffle.
Urza's Hot Tub.original_text: {2}, Discard a card: Search your library for a card that shares a complete word in its name with the discarded card, reveal it, and put it into your hand. Then shuffle your library.

Water Gun Balloon Game.name: Water Gun Balloon Game
Water Gun Balloon Game.text:
As Water Gun Balloon Game enters the battlefield, each player puts a pop! counter on "0."
Whenever a player casts a spell, move that player's pop! counter up one.
Whenever a player's pop! counter hits "5," that player creates a 5/5 pink Giant Teddy Bear creature token and resets all pop! counters to "0."
Water Gun Balloon Game.original_text:
As Water Gun Balloon Game comes into play, each player puts a pop counter on a 0.
Whenever a player plays a spell, move that player's pop counter up 1.
Whenever a player's pop counter hits 5, that player puts a 5/5 pink Giant Teddy Bear creature token into play and resets all pop counters to 0.

rulings.text: In a game with more than two players, players can use paper and pencil to track where their pop! counter is. That is, the tracker located in Water Gun Balloon Game’s art is fun, but not required to work.
Pink joins gold and every eye color imaginable in the set of colors in silver-bordered Magic games.

The pop! counters are considered to be on the inherent tracker in Water Gun Balloon Game’s art, not on the permanent itself. Those counters can’t be removed or moved to another permanent. Similarly, if you proliferate, you can’t add more pop! counters to Water Gun Balloon Game.

World-Bottling Kit.name: World-Bottling Kit
World-Bottling Kit.text: {5}, Sacrifice World-Bottling Kit: Choose a Magic set. Exile all permanents with that set's expansion symbol except for basic lands.
World-Bottling Kit.original_text: {5}, Sacrifice World-Bottling Kit: Choose a Magic set. Remove from the game all permanents with that set's expansion symbol except for basic lands.
